channel.title: Beware of paypal scam
channel.description:
I just received this email from:
August 9, 2010: We have reasons to believe that your account was accessed by a third party. Because protecting the security of your account is our primary concern, we have limited access to sensitive PayPal account features. We understand that this may be an inconvenience but please understand that this temporary limitation is for your protection. OPEN AND COMPLETE THE FORM ATTACHED IN THIS MESSAGE TO REGAIN ACCESS TO YOUR ACCOUNT. Also when you will complete the document we have sent, remember to ALLOW javascript to run from the bar that will pop-up, otherwise we cannot verify the informations you have provided.
There was an attached form, and from first glanced it looked legitimate, but closer looking and I realized that all of the button groups were actually images, from some random IP. Here is what the scam page looks like: [img]http://img227.imageshack.us/img227/3596/scam.png[/img] Notice that the entire group there is one image. If you get this page, EVER, report it to your email provider (so they can hopefully trace the email) I also have reason to believe that the person doing this got my email from this site, because the only people that know I have a server (which is the only way I do anything with paypal) are from here. Be careful everyone! NOTE: The person is using PHP xMailer, so it WILL say it's from PayPal! Don't be fooled!

item.title: Beware of paypal scam
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:353947”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=450243.msg3302974#msg3302974 date=1281448855]

TIP: Never fill out ‘attached’ forms, as 30-50% of them could be a scam. If possible, check for anything similar on the website they are claiming to be.

More like 100% of ‘attached’ forms are a scam. Any legitimate company will have you go to their website and sign in before requesting any type of information.

@this scam, paypal scams are all over the place, I must get at least one per week, just ignore them all and only go to paypal.com to do anything.

I have gotten many attached forms to fill out, that were legit. It all depends on what kind of site it is. Also “more than 100%”, I know that is an exhaduration, but come up with a plausible percentage that can ACTUALLY happen.
[/quote]

No decent site will EVER send you an attached form to fill out, they will instead LINK you to a form on their SECURE website.[/quote]Yea, I get those all the time, but then even some of them are scams. Like it will be the same mesage as what I have, but instead of attaching the form, it will say:

Visit our site and fill out the form to verify your account: [url=http://SCAMWEBSITE.com]http://www.PayPal.com/verify/~verifyform.php[/url]
(click the link to see what I mean)

That’s when you have to make sure you double check the address bar of wherever you visit.

Read full topic

item.title: Beware of paypal scam
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest

@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:11, topic:353947”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=450243.msg3302903#msg3302903 date=1281440464]

TIP: Never fill out ‘attached’ forms, as 30-50% of them could be a scam. If possible, check for anything similar on the website they are claiming to be.

More like 100% of ‘attached’ forms are a scam. Any legitimate company will have you go to their website and sign in before requesting any type of information.

@this scam, paypal scams are all over the place, I must get at least one per week, just ignore them all and only go to paypal.com to do anything.
[/quote]
I have gotten many attached forms to fill out, that were legit. It all depends on what kind of site it is. Also “more than 100%”, I know that is an exhaduration, but come up with a plausible percentage that can ACTUALLY happen.[/quote]

No decent site will EVER send you an attached form to fill out, they will instead LINK you to a form on their SECURE website.

Read full topic

[/quote]It was the first I’ve gotten, and it was somewhat disconcerting because I don’t use this email for a lot of other things besides private servers =/

Yea, I double checked the real paypal because it seemed suspicious.[/quote]That’s cause Mr. Mupar you’re rich and r-s dunt liek u.

item.title: Beware of paypal scam
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Typically you can tell when something is a scam by the grammar. In most cases, any official email from a site such a Paypal would never start a sentence with ‘also.’ Besides, there should be a comma after it too.

Read full topic

item.title: Beware of paypal scam
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I just received this email from:

August 9, 2010: We have reasons to believe that your account was accessed by a third party. Because protecting the security of your account is our primary concern, we have limited access to sensitive PayPal account features. We understand that this may be an inconvenience but please understand that this temporary limitation is for your protection. OPEN AND COMPLETE THE FORM ATTACHED IN THIS MESSAGE TO REGAIN ACCESS TO YOUR ACCOUNT.

Also when you will complete the document we have sent, remember to ALLOW javascript to run from the bar that will pop-up,
otherwise we cannot verify the informations you have provided.

There was an attached form, and from first glanced it looked legitimate, but closer looking and I realized that all of the button groups were actually images, from some random IP. Here is what the scam page looks like:

Notice that the entire group there is one image. If you get this page, EVER, report it to your email provider (so they can hopefully trace the email)

I also have reason to believe that the person doing this got my email from this site, because the only people that know I have a server (which is the only way I do anything with paypal) are from here.

Be careful everyone!

NOTE: The person is using PHP xMailer, so it WILL say it’s from PayPal! Don’t be fooled!

Read full topic
